titleStmt.title: Multimetric behavioral profile and psychological traits

analytic.title: Multimetric behavioral profile and psychological traits

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: External sources of information determine human actions. However, psychological traits (PTs), considered internal variables, also play a crucial role in decision-making. PTs are stable across time and contexts, and they define the set of behavioral repertoires that individuals express. Here, we explored how multiple metrics of adaptive behavior under uncertainty related to several PTs. Participants solved a multiple baseline reversal-learning task with volatile contingencies, from where we characterized a detailed behavioral profile based on a wide variety of measurements from their response sequences. We then tested the relationship between the multimetric behavioral profile and a wide range of self-reported psychological questionnaires. The PT measurements were based on the Hierarchical Taxonomy Of Psychopathology (HiTOP) model. We found that the learning curves alone predicted important differences in the PTs, and task response times. Similarly, the behavioral profile configurations predicted the PTs, and could be used as a 'fingerprint' to identify participants with a high certainty level. We discuss how this characterization could contribute to constructing a better nosological classification.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Humans continuously adapt their actions to a changing environment. They do so in particular and unique ways associated with each individual (Roberts, 2009;Sauce and Matzel, 2013;Byrom and Murphy, 2018). Decisional strategies adopted by persons depend on internal (individual/genetic differences) and external (decision features, situational and environmental factors) factors (Appelt et al., 2011;Sauce and Matzel, 2013). Thus, a current topic of intense research is the study of how psychological traits (PTs; v.gr., any domain of personality and cognitive functions) influence decision-making. PTs can be easily assessed through self-reporting questionnaires, and these traits persist over days, years, and even decades (Harris et al., 2016).

Analysis of the origin and classification of individual differences has led to a deeper understanding of human behavior (Byrom, 2013;Griffiths et al., 2014). Individual differences manifest as time-consistent features (traits) or as time-and context-dependent features (states). Recent evidence suggests that people use distinct sources and amounts of information to update their task-solving strategies, particularly in volatile environments (Behrens et al., 2007;Hilbig, 2008;Michalkiewicz and Erdfelder, 2016). The adaptive mechanisms that deal with uncertainty have been linked to specific genes, brain circuits, and PTs (Allport, 1961;Lewis and Kim, 2009). Thus, maybe not surprisingly, PTs have been found to predict some differences in contingency learning and goal-directed behavior (Msetfi et al., 2015;Gillan et al., 2017). For example, anxious individuals learn poorly in uncertain environments (Browning et al., 2015); depressive traits predict impairments in context processing (Msetfi et al., 2005); people diagnosed with obsessive-compulsive disorder (Gillan et al., 2011) and with schizotypy/schizophrenia (Le Pelley et al., 2010;Morris et al., 2013;Morris et al., 2018) exhibit impaired goal-directed behavior and associative learning capacities (Haselgrove and Evans, 2010). Therefore, self-reported psychological measurements can be linked to differential behavioral manifestations (see v.gr. (Griffiths et al., 2019).

Using a series of forced-choice and reversal-learning tasks, we have recently shown how humans (and mice) exhibit idiosyncratic but stable choice biases across tasks and days (Treviño et al., 2020;Trevino et al., 2021). These findings revealed that at least a portion of the biases observed derived from internal variables that were entirely independent of the sensory and contextual elements involved in the tasks. The consistency in the behavioral phenotypes extracted from individuals when solving our tasks made us wonder whether these profiles could inform psychological traits, mental disorders, and maybe even psychopathologies (Neuringer, 2002).

Here, we explored whether multiple behavioral metrics (i.e., an extensive behavioral profile) of neurotypicals solving a perceptual task predicted individual differences in their PTs. We first assessed the PTs with questionnaires covering six specters from the Hierarchical Taxonomy Of Psychopathology (HiTOP) model. The HiTOP is an empirically driven, quantitative classification system that constructs the notion of psychopathological syndromes based on co-variation of symptoms (Kotov et al., 2017).

We choose the HiTOP because it simplifies the idea of PTs into wide, hierarchically arranged specters: thought disorder (e.g., schizotypal personality), somatoform (e.g., somatization disorder), internalizing (e.g., state and trait anxiety), disinhibited externalizing (e.g., impulsivity), detachment (e.g., anhedonia), antagonistic externalizing (e.g., narcissism). Next, we tested the same individuals in a reversal-learning task with volatile contingencies and quantified multiple behavioral features when solving the task. We found that schizotypy and anxiety traits exhibited learning differences in reward and volatility estimations both in stable and randomized rewarding conditions. In contrast, somatoform traits exhibited differences in volatility estimates only in stable rewarding conditions. Using multiple linear regression (MLRM) analyses, we confirmed that the behavioral profiles predicted the PTs above chance levels and classified the participants. These significant relationships imply that the behavioral responses when solving the reversal-learning task contained information about the PTs, and predict the subjects' identity.
Our results provide a simple yet powerful example of how objective psychometric and psychological measurements explain potential differences in the more broadly used neuropsychological scales.

div.head: Participants.
div.p: We conducted experiments in a total of 152 neurotypicals (72 women and 80 men; age range (yr.): 17-40, mode: 19; with approval from the ethical committee of our institution: ET092018-271). Most participants were dextral (85%), without visual impairments, diagnosis of neurological disorders, or drug abuse history. We gave all participants written instructions on how to respond to the questionnaires and solve the task. Before being tested, participants performed a brief pre-training phase to obtain 20 consecutive correct trials using the reversal-learning task (described below).

div.head: Assessment of psychological traits (PTs).
div.p: We characterized participant's PTs based on HiTOP specters (Kotov et al., 2017) by applying a series of paper (i.e., printed forms) and electronic questionnaires (using Google Forms; self-report) with no time limit. We focused on the following specters: 1) Thought Disorder: Schizotypal Personality Questionnaire (SPQ); seventy-four items (Raine, 1991); 2) Somatoform: Othmer and DeSouza Test for Detection of Somatization Disorder; seven items (Othmer and DeSouza, 1985); 3) Internalizing: State and trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI; split by two subscales); forty items (Spielberger et al., 1970); 4) Disinhibited Externalizing: Plutchik Impulsivity Scale, El; fifteen items (Plutchik and Van Praag, 1989); 5) Detachment: Revised Physical Anhedonia Scale (RPhA); sixty-six (Chapman et al., 1976); 6) Antagonistic Externalizing: Hypersensitive Narcissism Scale, (HSNS); ten items (Hendin and Cheek, 1997). A psychologist carried out the HiTOP testing, employing validated scales for Spanish-speaking people (García et al., 2002). We also included some socio-demographic questions (gender, age, native language).

div.head: Analysis of PTs.
div.p: We made histograms of the normalized scales from the PTs from a group of participants and calculated the distribution fits using normal density functions. We then took the mean () and standard deviation () as distribution parameters. We employed a linear regression model to compare PTs estimated using paper and electronic questionnaires. From these fits, we extracted the slope (m), coefficient of determination (R 2 ), root-mean-squared error (RMSE), and the P-value for the F-test on the model (which tests whether the model fits better than a constant term). We explored the possibility that an underlying 'latent' structure explained the average responses from the seven HiTOP specters (e.g., (Gillan et al., 2016). For that, we employed a factor analysis model (with three factors max. given the number of observed variables) using maximum likelihood estimation (MLE).

Reversal-learning task. We adapted a two-alternative match-to-sample task to include a second forcedchoice phase independent of the first choice. We have described this task in detail previously (Trevino et al., 2021). Briefly, participants sat upright in front of a computer monitor as we used a joystick to record their choices (Thrustmaster 2960623 USB Joystick). The visual stimuli (416 x 300 pixels; visual angle: 7° x 5°) consisted of two pictures displayed simultaneously on a single 27-inch computer monitor (Dell P2414H; 60 cm away from the participants' eyes). These two images had low semantic attributes, as validated before (Trevino et al., 2020). We manipulated the task difficulty by generating distracter images (i.e., the S  , delta, or non-rewarded stimulus) by using pictures with different similarities (SIM) relative to the sample stimulus (i.e., the S D , discriminative, or rewarded stimulus). Participants had to press the joystick towards one direction indicated by instructive arrows projected on the screen's center to solve the task. Choice regions corresponded to 5% of the total search space. The response times (RT, in s) were quantified and stored as the interval between the visual stimuli' presentation and when participants put the joystick in one of the available response regions. The participants had to let the joystick return to its baseline position after choosing. They had to make a visual choice during the first forced-choice phase based on identifying the side (left or right) where the S D was projected for 1 s. Two left and right white arrows appeared at the center of the display after the visual stimuli were projected.

The possible response options were shown by these arrows and stayed on the screen until the participant replied. Next, the SD was projected at the center of the screen for 750 ms or 3 s, respectively, depending on whether the participant responded correctly or incorrectly (i.e., a 1:4 relationship in the waiting intervals). During the second forced-choice phase, two white arrows at the center of the screen pointing to the upper right and left corners indicated the two response options. Here, we reinforced random sidechoices (using balanced randomly permuted locations) or left or right side-choices (Trevino et al., 2020;Trevino et al., 2021). The waiting intervals that we employed after participants responded reinforced particular side choices: 750 ms after correct side-choices and 3 s after incorrect side-choices.

Thus, the implicit motivation for solving the task was to discriminate correctly (phase 1) and choose the correct side (phase 2) to finish the task promptly. We switched the contingencies for the second choice every 60 trials for 12 blocks/day. All our projection and analysis software was written in (MathWorks, Inc.; Natick, USA) using the Psychophysics Toolbox extensions (PTB-3).

div.head: Multimetric behavioral profile.
div.p: We used a training paradigm with contingencies that favored either random or side-choices, and participants selected the left or right sides during the 2 nd side-choice phase of the reversal-learning task (Trevino et al., 2020). Next, we implemented a detailed analysis of these side-choices, as described before (Trevino et al., 2021). Briefly, we took the block-averaged choice records from each participant (y) and fitted them with linear regressions from where we quantified the slopes (m). We also adjusted mono-exponential curves with the form:

where corresponds to the maximum average performance achieved during the block, y 0 is the initial % Correct responses (a free parameter in the fitting procedure), x are the trials within the block, and  is the rise constant, equivalent to the learning rate constant in associative learning models such as Rescorla and Wagner (1972).
Using a Bayesian learning (BL) algorithm, we estimated the reward (r) and volatility (v) probabilities given the history of trial outcomes (rewards) (Behrens et al., 2007;Trevino et al., 2021).

The BL constitutes a Markovian Decision Process (MDP; (Sutton and Barto, 1998)) which means that a choice made at a particular trial depends on the information the agent had from the previous trial. Thus, the BL algorithm computes a three-dimensional density function of r, v, and k (the rate of change of v) for every trial. r (or v) is a weighted mean of the marginal distribution integrated by v (or r) and k. A complete breakdown of the BL equations and methods can be found in the original publication's supplementary material by Timothy Behrens and colleagues (Behrens et al., 2007).
To assess overall choice biases, we used the stationary (Shannon) entropy:
where s is the response side (left or right).
To measure the level of unpredictability of the transitions between consecutive choices (Shiferaw et al., 2019), we measured the transition entropy for side-choices as follows:
where s i is the response side (left or right), and s i-1 is the prior response side (left or right). These entropy values ranged between 0 and 1.

We applied multiple linear regression models (MLRM) to explore the relationship between behavioral attributes extracted from the reversal-learning task and the PTs (Chamorro et al., 2017;Trevino et al., 2020).

Statistical analysis. We used t-tests, non-parametric tests, and Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) tests for group and distribution comparisons. As a reference to determine the significance of the MLRM regression coefficients, we created surrogate data sets (n = 1000) using random permutations of the predictors, as previously described (Chamorro et al., 2017;Trevino et al., 2021). We reduced the regression coefficients' space into three dimensions (3D) using principal component analysis (PCA). We illustrate our group data as averages ± S.E.M. with a significance set at P  0.05. The number of participants used for each task's analysis is represented inside parentheses in the corresponding figure panels.

div.head: Assessment of psychological traits through self-report questionnaires
div.p: We first characterized the psychological traits (PTs) from 111 neurotypicals using electronic questionnaires based on seven HiTOP specters (Kotov et al., 2017); see Methods). Frequency histograms and their Gaussian fits are illustrated in Figure 1A. We validated the usage of such electronic surveys on another group of 41 naïve participants by contrasting the estimated traits through electronic surveys relative to conventional paper (i.e., printed) questionnaires ( Figure 1B). As expected, all comparisons exhibited strong positive correlations and coefficients of determination (R 2 ; Figure 1C), with the strongest electronic/paper similarities when comparisons involved the same trait (slopes and R 2 from paired variables in Figure 1D). Given the high correlations across traits, we explored the possibility that some of these specters shared some underlying mechanisms. We performed factor analysis using the average responses from the seven questionnaires. The two-and three-factor analyses revealed distinctive trait compositions (two-factor analysis | F1: low anhedonia; F2: high anhedonia;

three-factor analysis | F1: low anhedonia and impulsivity, which are linked to some neuropsychiatric disorders (Houeto et al., 2016); F2: low anhedonia with high impulsivity and anxiety trait, where anhedonia has been associated with transitions between anxiety and depression (Winer et al., 2017); F3: high anhedonia and somatoform; Figure 1E). This result suggests that some of the PTs shared an underlying correlative structure. Hence PTs were not entirely independent from each other. Strong consistency for electronic/paper assessments revealed by pairwise comparisons of normalized scales using the linear regression slopes (top panel) and R 2 (bottom panel) Empty squares correspond to n.s. interactions (i.e., the model can be represented as a constant term). (E) two-(pie charts on top) and three-(pie charts on bottom) factor analysis on the seven specters' average responses. Color codes indicate the constitution of specters for each factor. Number of subjects in parenthesis.

div.head: Multimetric behavioral profiles extracted from a reversal-learning task
div.p: Once we characterized their PTs, we took the original 111 participants and tested their discriminative and adaptive responses when solving a multiple reversal-learning task. We used a two-alternative matchto-sample task, which allowed us to measure discrimination performance (1 st visual choice) and sidechoices (2 nd forced-choice) during two sequential phases within each trial (see Methods; Figure | 3 2A) (Trevino et al., 2020;Trevino et al., 2021). We controlled task difficulty for the 1 st visual choice using linear mixtures of the S  and S D images leading to different degrees of stimulus similarity (SIM;

using Matlab function 'imlincomb', with k = 0.8-1, Figure 2B). For the 2 nd forced side-choice, we used variable or stationary rewarding contingencies by reinforcing: i) random, ii) left-only, or iii) right-only sequences. In this task, reward involved waiting for a shorter interval coupled with a green feedback screen ( Figure 2C; see Methods). The training blocks were arranged so that participants underwent all possible transitions ( Figure 2D).
Visual choices depended on stimulus discriminability (F = 26.8, P < 0.001), with performance dropping when k 1 (logistic fit (Trevino et al., 2018): y max = 0.35,  = 60.74, x 50 = 0.96, Figure 2E).

Optimal performance in volatile tasks involves combining a dynamic adjustment of evidence's weighting with prior expectations (Behrens et al., 2007;Lawson et al., 2017). Because our task involved a sequence of two choices within each trial, we explored for sequential effects, but found none (F = 4.17, P = 0.06), with the side-choices following a random process (rnd, binomial distribution; caramelbrown; F = 0.35, P = 0.55; Figure 2F), fully independent of stimulus discriminability (F = 1.26, P = 0.28; Figure 2G). Next, we quantified a moving average of the participants' % correct side-choices (blue line corresponds to group averaged choices, span = 40 trials, Figure 2H). As expected, participants exhibited various learning rates based on how they used the feedback information (Pulcu and Browning, 2017;Trevino et al., 2021). We grouped the learning curves by reinforcement conditions and found no net left vs. right bias (Kruskal-Wallis multi-comparison test, P < 0.001; Figure 2H). We also took the block-averaged choice records from each participant and fitted them with linear regressions and mono-exponential curves. We extracted the corresponding slopes (m), rising taus (), and peak values (; not illustrated; (Trevino et al., 2021). We also quantified the participants' response times (RT, in s) for visual and side-choices. To summarize: the lack of sequential effects in this task allowed us to | 2 make a robust characterization of discriminative capacities and adaptive responses to volatile contingencies separately. The 1 st choice did not produce sequential effects for the 2 nd choice, which followed a random binomial process (caramel-brown distribution). (G) Average %correct side-choice (2 nd choice) is fully independent from stimulus discriminability. (H) Average %correct side-choice records (2 nd choice, blue line), with left (vanilla yellow background), right (flax yellow background), or volatile (i.e., random; empty background) reinforcements. (I) Block averaged learning curves associated with the three reinforcement scenarios. Number of subjects in parenthesis.

An optimal Bayesian learning model predicts response times Our reversal-learning task contains contingencies that create expected and unexpected uncertainties (Pulcu and Browning, 2019). Expected uncertainty emerges with probabilistic reinforcement (random but balanced reinforcement), whereas unexpected uncertainty arises from the experimental design's implied volatility (when the reinforcement conditions change between blocks; Figure 2D). We implemented a Bayesian Learning (BL) algorithm (see Methods) to estimate the sources of uncertainty in our task. This ideal observer model takes the reward rate from previous observations and transforms the agent's belief about the task's state by updating representations of reward and volatility through multivariate probability distributions (Behrens et al., 2007;Trevino et al., 2021). Therefore, to quantify individual differences in the feedback experience when solving the reversal-learning task, we fitted the BL to the choice data from each participant. The algorithm calculated and returned the reward (r) and volatility (v) estimates as a function of the experimental trials (group averaged responses illustrated in Figure 3A).The hierarchical aspect of the model has been discussed before (Trevino et al., 2021).

We next averaged the BL estimations from the four training blocks per participant (experimental time-line in the lower panel of Figure 3A). The averaged r estimation rates (black) were similar for left and right reinforcement (left | 84.65% 1.01%; right | 83.89% 0.93%; n = 111), but were 40% smaller with alternating reinforcement (alternation | 49.28% 0.38%; non-parametric Kruskal-Wallis test with Bonferroni correction, P < 0.001; Figure 3B). Faster changes in r estimations reflect a greater influence of recently experienced events (Pulcu and Browning, 2019). Likewise, v (kelly green) were, on average, similar for left and right reinforcements (left | 0.17 02; right | 0.17 01; n = 111), but they were 30% higher with random reinforcements (alternation | 0.22 02; P < 0.001; Figure 3B). Figure 3B illustrate how the participants exhibited a wide range of choice variability, | 2 r, and v estimates, particularly when solving our task's uncertain components (see also (Pulcu and Browning, 2019).

div.head: Figure 2H,I, and
div.p: We wondered whether r and v estimates were sensitive to attentional factors. We reasoned that these values should differ between trials that led to correct and incorrect choices (Trevino et al., 2016).

We extracted the response times (RTs) from correct and incorrect choices ( Figure 3C), and employed linear regression models (using "fitlm" function from MATLAB; modelspec: "linear") to test whether these RTs exhibited a dependency to r (Figure 3D) and v estimates ( Figure 3E). Interestingly, when reinforcing same-side choices, lower RTs were associated with higher r values for correct but not incorrect trials. RTs also increased with v estimates for correct but not for incorrect choices. This result shows how the sensitivity of the RTs to r and v could be used as an indirect measure of confidence by the participants, where lower v estimates are associated with faster responses (Zylberberg et al., 2016).

div.head: Figure 3 | Reward and volatility estimations through a Bayesian Learning model. (A)
div.p: Calculated reward (r) and volatility (v) estimations using an optimal Bayesian learning algorithm (see Methods; (Behrens et al., 2007).

div.head: Bayesian learning estimations contain information about the PTs
div.p: Median splits constitute a useful and legitimate approach for examining relationships between factors and dependent variables (Iacobucci et al., 2015). The method consists of forming two subgroups depending on whether the PT scores were greater or smaller than the group median before performing further analyses (Trevino, 2014;Trevino et al., 2016). Therefore, we divided the PT scores into strong and weak groups (median split) to analyze whether the BL estimates contained trait information. In agreement, we found that estimates for schizotypy (trait #1), somatoform (trait #2), anxiety state (trait #3), and anxiety trait (trait #4) unveiled Bayesian computation differences (asterisks depict a P 0.05, with a Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, Figure 4). In many of these cases, the r and v estimation curves from 'strong' and 'weak' groups remained well-separated throughout the training block. This outcome implies that some of the PTs may be correlated with unique learning processes, as understood from an optimal Bayesian learning perspective. Therefore, such learning differences should be useful to understand PTs (Murphy and Msetfi, 2014).

div.head: Figure 4 | Relationship between Bayesian learning estimates and some psychological traits. Panels
div.p: show Bayesian reward (r; superior learners: continuous black line, inferior learners: dotted red line) and volatility (v; superior learners: continuous kelly green line, inferior learners: dotted navy blue line) estimates from participants forming 'higher' and 'lower' performers. This was achieved using a median split of the participant's r and v estimates and tracking their corresponding PTs (asterisks depict a P 0.05, using a Kolmogorov-Smirnov test). Number of subjects in parenthesis.

div.head: Behavioral profile quantified with the reversal-learning task predicts PTs
div.p: The reversal-learning task helped us to characterize a learning 'fingerprint' from each participant (Trevino et al., 2021). To further explore the link between the behavioral factors from the reversallearning task (i.e., the predictors) and the PTs (i.e., the response variables), we employed a multivariable linear regression model (MLRM; Figure 5A). We collected a total of 24 behavioral metrics extracted from the reversal-learning task (i.e., a multimetric behavioral profile), including the stationary and transition entropies (Trevino et al., 2021). Using correlation analysis, we found that many of the predictors and response variables were not entirely independent from each other ( Figure 5B). This suggests that the behavioral profile could be condensed into a more compact and powerful version.

div.head: Figure | Multivariate linear regression model. (A)
div.p: Tables illustrate the seven response variables (i.e., the PTs, enclosed in a dotted rectangle) and the 24 predictors extracted from the reversal-learning task (tea green background). We combined predictors with the PTs and applied a multivariable linear regression model (MLRM) to extract empirical slopes (Trevino et al., 2021). (B) The high crosscorrelation coefficients across pairs of predictors (left panel) and response variables (right panel) reveal that many of these parameters are not fully independent from each other.

We then conducted the MLRM analyses and plotted the regression coefficients' strength as colored squares as a function of each block's training trial. We established the coefficients' empirical significance by comparing their values against 1000 regressions obtained with randomly permuted predictors (see Methods). We took P 0.05 as a threshold and plotted non-significant (n.s.) coefficients as empty (i.e., white) rectangles ( Figure 6A). All these panels confirm that behavioral features extracted from the reversal-learning task contained information about the PTs' strength. To assess and visualize the differences across PT regressors, we plotted the three main principal components (PC) of the regression coefficients in a Cartesian coordinate system (each PT is represented with a point, error bars are standard deviations; Figure 6B). In addition, to assess the similarity across regression coefficients, we calculated the Euclidean distances (from the three PCs) across pairs of PTs (Figure 6C). Small distances imply overall similar MLRM regression coefficients, difficulting discrimination of PTs. In contrast, large distances imply a good discriminability of PTs by using the behavioral attributes from the reversal-learning task. Figures 6B and 6C revealed that anxiety state stand out from the rest, with more similar behavioral configurations for the remainder of the PTs. The MLRM analysis reveals that a multimetric behavioral profile can be used to classify and complement large self-reported personality questionnaires. predictors, with their strength identified by using a step-wise regression learner (Trevino et al., 2021). Stronger predictors render more accurate classification. Number of subjects in parenthesis.

div.head: Behavioral attributes from the reversal-learning task as an individuality measure
div.p: Because the MLRM analyses revealed a strong relationship between predictors from the reversallearning task and the PTs, we next explored the possibility of using the information in such behavioral features to identify the participants. We implemented a simple linear classifier that minimized the difference between partial and final predictors, as described before (Trevino et al., 2020;Trevino et al., 2021). We rated their predictive power on the response variables (i.e., the PTs) using a step-wise regression learning procedure (Matlab Regression Learner App; (Trevino et al., 2021). The predictors sorted in order of importance were: 1, 16,5,10,17,12,7,11,6,13,18,14,2,19,3,4,20,22,23,15,9,21,24, 8 (these numeric IDs correspond to predictors displayed in Figure 5A). Notably, the best predictor for all PTs was |m| (rectified slope), which constitutes a raw, yet powerful metric of the learning rate. We created the cumulative characteristic curves by using increasing epoch durations. As anticipated, we found that prediction accuracy increased with epoch duration (against classifications made with 1000 random permutations of the predictors; rnd in caramel-brown). Also, prediction accuracy improved faster when using stronger predictors (tangerine and carmine reds; predictors contained within percentiles 75%-100%: 1, 16, 5, 10, 17, 12; Figure 6D). This result indicates that multimetric behavioral predictors exhibited different predictive power to identify the participants.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Using a multiple-baseline reversal-learning task, we characterized how individuals adopted various strategies linked to different error checking levels and heterogeneous learning curves. These learning curves and other behavioral parameters were specific for each individual (Byrom and Murphy, 2018;Trevino et al., 2021). Such individual differences in human associative learning substantially impact adaptive strategies in rapidly changing environments. Some disruptions in such adaptive behaviors have been associated with some cognitive aspects of psychopathology (Corlett et al., 2009).

Human learning flexibility can be integrated into a general framework in which model parameters represent and lead to variance in learning (Rescorla and Wagner, 1972;Trevino et al., 2011;Byrom, 2013;Glautier, 2013;Trevino, 2015;2020).

It has been shown that different amounts of uncertainty influence how decision-makers use previous events to guide their choices. Expected uncertainty reduces the amount of information that individual trials provide (i.e., an optimal strategy is to rely on a wider choice-history window). In contrast, unexpected uncertainty involves a radical change in reinforcement conditions that require quick adaptation (i.e., the optimal strategy is to rely on a short choice-history window; (Pulcu and Browning, 2019). Trial and error learning algorithms provide powerful explanations of how humans can learn to choose actions that result in more rewards and fewer punishments. Similarly, Bayesian learning models (BL) assess how individuals learn about environments with expected and unexpected changes in probabilistic relationships (Lawson et al., 2017). We employed an optimal BL to estimate how participants adapted to changes in expected and unexpected sources of uncertainty (Pulcu and Browning, 2019). The BL algorithm allowed us to characterize each participant's reward (r) and volatility (v) estimates while learning about the reversal-learning task. We explored the possibility of an attentional component regulating the r and v estimations and found that the response times (RTs) depended on r and | 3 v estimations for correct but not incorrect choices. These RT differences represent an indirect measure of confidence in the task (Zylberberg et al., 2016). It remains an open question how the RT distributions relate to the BL and confidence estimations (Whelan, 2008;Trevino et al., 2016;Trevino, 2020).

We characterized the psychological traits (PTs) of the participants using the HiTOP scale (Kotov et al., 2017). Although there are other relevant classification systems (Costa and McCrae, 1992;Gillan et al., 2016), we chose PTs based on specters from the HiTOP due to the recent and intense research behind it. Interestingly, although it's clear that PTs influence learning in humans (Msetfi et al., 2017), these effects are not generally integrated into associative learning models (Rescorla and Wagner, 1972;Le Pelley, 2004;Esber and Haselgrove, 2011). Our results revealed r and v estimation differences in anxious and schizotypal individuals solving the reversal-learning task were probably due to an impaired reconfiguration between expected and unexpected uncertainty strategies (Corlett et al., 2009).

Moreover, our results showed that behavioral parameters extracted from the reversal-learning task contained PT information and confirmed the idea that anxious individuals perform worst in volatile environments (Browning et al., 2015). Our approach involved using a robust multimetric behavioral characterization to describe the learning curves and their relationship with the psychometric scales. The analysis revealed that some PTs (e.g., somatoform, anxiety trait, impulsivity) had similar behavioral manifestations and maybe even a common internal variation source impacting such behavioral outputs.
In contrast, anxiety state was the PT associated with the most distinguishable behavioral profile.

Beyond the well-known disruptions in latent inhibition and blocking, previous works have shown how schizophrenia patients and with schizotypy exhibit impaired stimulus salience (Haselgrove and Evans, 2010;Byrom, 2013) and context (Uhlhaas and Silverstein, 2005) processing capacities.

Misestimating the sources of uncertainty leads to sub-optimal behavior. It could reflect a failure to detect the state of complex environments or to choose the correct course of action. Difficulties in estimating | 2 uncertainty could be one mechanism linked to disorders like depression, anxiety, and neuroticism, which show learning difficulties (Pulcu and Browning, 2019). Obsessive-compulsive disorders (OCD) are also driven by deficiencies in the way participants update their behavior and establish confidence about the tasks being solved (Gillan et al., 2016;Seow and Gillan, 2020). Adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) exhibit intolerance to change and tend to overestimate the sensory environment's volatility (Lawson et al., 2017).

We found that schizotypy, somatoform, and anxiety states predicted some differences in the behavioral attributes from the reversal-learning task. These results raise the possibility of using learning estimates (e.g., v) to detect differences in this population. Moreover, reversal-learning tasks have been used to investigate PTs given their sensitive properties to identify individual differences (Budhani et al., 2006;Gillan et al., 2016;Dargis et al., 2017). Using a multivariable linear regression model, we showed how behavioral differences on the reversal-learning task contained information about the PTs from the HiTOP specters. The strongest predictor was tightly linked to a raw metric of the learning rate. We also found that behavioral parameters extracted from the reversal-learning task acted as sensitive trait variables that individuals exhibited while solving the task (i.e., cross-situationally consistent behavior; (Allport, 1961;Harris et al., 2016). It would be crucial to confirm that these behavioral metrics are consistent across situations (Trevino et al., 2021) and whether they are enduring, namely, if they hold test-retest reliability in intervals ranging from days to weeks even to years (Harris et al., 2016).

Previous work suggests that some personality traits are linked to elevated levels of delay discounting (reduction in the present value of a delayed outcome), such as some psychiatric conditions, personality/ disorders, pathological gambling, drug abuse, among others (Odum, 2011). Impulsivity can also be characterized as a desire for rapid over long-term rewards (increased delayed discounting of rewards) and decreased cognitive capability (Bobova et al., 2009). Internal and external causes interact, | 3 conforming a complicated and integrated network of interactions that could explain the learning differences between individuals in a population (Sauce and Matzel, 2013).

One of the main limitations of our work is that we assumed that participants behaved as optimal Bayesian learners. However, it is still under debate which model offers the best description of how humans estimate uncertainty (Pulcu and Browning, 2019). Correlational approaches and regressions help explore the influence of certain variables on behavioral output across individuals. Still, these approaches have limited capacity to understand behavior. A general mechanism or a theoretical framework is crucial to understand these relationships (Byrom and Murphy, 2018). Indeed, more research is needed to explore and isolate which factors underlie individual behavioral differences.

In synthesis, we presented an exploratory study that related behavioral responses to a reversallearning task with seven PT specters from the HiTOP scale. We implemented a robust behavioral characterization to construct multimetric behavioral profiles of the participants. We found that such behavioral profiles served as a behavioral signature from the participants and predicted the PTs.

figure.head: Figure 1 |
figure.figDesc: Assessment of psychological traits with the HiTOP scale. (A) Frequency histograms for seven normalized traits, with their Gaussian fits for electronic assessments made in 111 participants. Last panel shows box-and-whiskers plots (box: 25 th and 75 th quantiles; whiskers: th and 95 th percentiles). (B) Validation of the measurement of the HiTOP dimensions comparing electronic vs. paper printed questionnaires. Red lines are linear regressions. (C) List of the seven traits with the slopes (m), coefficients of determination (R 2 ), and P values from the linear regressions shown in panel B. (D)

figure.head: Figure 2 |
figure.figDesc: Behavioral profiles of participants solving a reversal-learning task. (A) Drawing of our experimental apparatus. (B) Variable discrmination difficulty by linear mixtures of two source images. (C) Stimulus time-line of the reversal-learning task (see Methods). (D) Time-line depicting the experimental contingencies. (E) Visual psychometric performance. (F)

(B) Averaged r and v associated with the reinforcement conditions from the | 2 reversal-learning task. (C) Group average response times (RT, in s) for correct (blue) and incorrect (red) choices. Inset shows the experimental time-line. Panels on the right side show scatter plots of RTs as a function of r (D) and v (E). Number of subjects in parenthesis.

figure.head: Figure 6 |
figure.figDesc: Interdependence between behavioral attributes from the reversal-learning task and psychological traits. (A) Regression slopes for the MLRM as a function of the trials within each block. Empty rectangles represent non-significant (n.s.) slopes (see Methods). (B) Implementation of principal component analysis (PCA) for dimensionality reduction of our regression coefficients into three main dimensions. Fraction of explained variance: PC1: 71.46%  5.13%, PC2: 12.55%  2.27%, PC3: 5.85%  1.44%. (C) Euclidean distances across pairs of PTs. Bigger distances imply stronger differences between regression coefficients. (D) Cumulative match curves calculated using different sets of | 3

div.head: Conflict of Interest
div.p: The authors declare that the research was conducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could be considered a potential conflict of interest. Author Contributions Conceptualization: MT and SC; Methodology: MT and SC; Resources: MT; Supervision: MT, BV, and PO; Investigation: MT, SC, BV, PO, and RM; Visualization: MT and RM; Writingoriginal draft: MT; Writingreview & editing: MT and SC; Funding Acquisition: MT. Funding This study was supported by the Consejo Nacional de Ciencia y Tecnología (CONACYT, grant #220862 to MT), Programa para el Fortalecimiento de Cuerpos Académicos, SEP, 2018 (Análisis de la función de redes neuronales, UDG-CA-927), and Programa de Fortalecimiento de la Investigación y el Posgrado 2020 (Centro Universitario de Ciencias Biológicas y Agropecuarias, Universidad de Guadalajara, to MT). RMC received a M.Sc. scholarship from CONACYT (#966763). SC received a Ph.D. scholarship from the University of Guadalajara (V/2018/1476).

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: We thank B. Haro for recruiting participants and helping validate the electronic/paper questionnaires. Special thanks to Dr. M. Torres Morán and her team from Coordinación de Investigación CUCBA, UdeG, for their continuous help and support. We thank the University of Guadalajara for funding the doctoral studies of SC (V/2018/1476).
